In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

1 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In 2009, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) launched a sanitation dialogue1 between 
ADB and the developing member countries. The objective of the workshop was to provide a 
forum for issues associated with poor sanitation, in order to take up the sanitation challenge and 
avert a crisis in the making. Viet Nam followed suit by organizing an In-Country Sanitation 
Dialogue in April 2009 to discuss its own specific sanitation issues, and practical and affordable 
solutions.  The  2010  Viet  Nam  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  Assessment,  Strategy,  and 
Roadmap  highlights  that  urban  wastewater  management  is  lagging  overall  urban  and 
socioeconomic development in Viet Nam. Official statistics provided by the Government of Viet 
Nam as part of monitoring the Millennium Development Goals indicate that 88% of the urban 
population has ―access to improved sanitation facilities.‖ However, these data give no indication 
of the lack of safe disposal of wastewater that causes health and environmental problems. The 
government has requested ADB assistance to prepare its institutions and agencies for their role 
in delivering urban environmental improvement policies, targets, and programs.  
 
2.  Following consultation with most of the development partners, ADB and the Ministry of 
Construction (MOC) met on 20 September 2010 for a technical assistance (TA) fact-finding 
mission to discuss and finalize proposed capacity development TA for Support to Central and 
Local Government to Implement Urban Environment Improvement Programs2. The TA is the 
first step in ADB's long-term engagement with the Government of Viet Nam in general, and 
MOC in particular, on urban wastewater management in Viet Nam. The TA will run concurrently 
with a series of project preparatory TA during 2011 and 2012, leading to major investment in 
urban wastewater management from 2013.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Less than 10% of urban wastewater in Viet Nam is centrally treated. The majority of 
urban households use inadequately maintained on-site sanitation such as septic tanks, resulting 
in partial treatment and environmental pollution. The continued discharge of untreated and 
partially treated municipal wastewater is a threat to the dwindling freshwater resources of Viet 
Nam. The recent water sector review3 concluded that reliable water availability within several of 
Viet Nam’s river basins is at risk, especially in the dry season. In a country with about 3,000 
kilometers of coastline and growing pressure from climate change, coastal areas and coastal 
cities are particularly sensitive, because lots of users rely on self-supply from the underground 
aquifer, resulting in microbiological and organic contamination from on-site sanitation systems 
and increased salinity. 
 
4.  The urban population of Viet Nam is growing at one of the fastest rates in Asia, fuelled 
by  a  rapidly  expanding  economy  that  is  largely  built  on  industrialization.  In  such  rapidly 
developing urban areas with increasing population density, and increasing per capita water 
consumption,  more  environmentally  acceptable  means  of  wastewater  disposal,  and  proper 
operation and maintenance of on-site and off-site wastewater facilities, are required.  
 
5.  In recognition of this growing threat to health and environment, the government has 
formulated ambitious targets to have 70% of cities equipped with adequate sewerage systems 
by 2025. Prime Minister’s Decision 1930/2009.4 The draft Socioeconomic Development Plan,

2011–2015 places considerable emphasis on better performance by the government in reducing 
the environmental impact of municipal and industrial waste discharge. The cost to meet this 
target is estimated at about $20 billion over 15 years (footnote 3).  
 
6.  As  a  consequence  of  the  government’s  cornerstone  policy  of  decentralization,  the 
responsibility for urban infrastructure (implementation and operation and maintenance) now 
rests with local governments, whereas, under Decree 88/2007,5 the central government remains 
responsible for the financing of capital investment. At the same time, the legal framework 
encourages water and sewerage services to operate on commercial principles, enabling local 
governments and utility companies to raise tariffs to full cost recovery6 for water supply and cost 
recovery7 for wastewater, with an allowance for subsidies from the local governments. However, 
most local governments do not have the financial and technical capacity to manage the scale, 
complexity,  and  cost  of  urban  environment  programs.  Many  of  the  urban  environmental 
companies (URENCOs) or water supply and sewerage companies are not yet fully prepared to 
operate on commercial principles and attract private sector financing and expertise. Neither do 
these utility companies have access to capital markets. Massive capacity building effort is 
required to implement urban wastewater management systems on a large scale. The TA will 
supplement the ongoing efforts by various development partners.  
 
7.  Development partners are financing some urban wastewater improvement programs on 
the basis of concessional lending and grant funding. Japan International Cooperation Agency 
has been a pioneer in financing large-scale sewerage projects in Binh Duong, Ha Noi, Hai 
Phong, Ho Chi Minh City, Hue, and Vinh Phuc. The World Bank is assisting the Government of 
Viet Nam in formulating a Unified Sanitation Sector Strategy and Action Plan (U3SAP), while 
financing sewerage projects in Ho Chi Minh City and several coastal cities and for the upcoming 
Urban Environment Upgrading Program.8 The first examples of central sewerage systems with 
separate networks are in Da Lat, Lam Dong Province and Buon Ma Thuot, Dak Lak Province, 
supported by Danish International Development Agency grant funding. Germany is supporting 
an  integrated  wastewater  and  solid  waste  management  program  in  six  provinces,  with 
considerable emphasis on capacity building at local level. Finland is supporting water supply 
and sewerage projects in small towns in the northern provinces. The Australian Agency for 
International  Development  has  commissioned  the  University  of  Technology,  Sydney  to 
investigate  the  economics  of  different  sanitation  options,  resulting  in  a  demonstrated  cost 
effectiveness of decentralized solutions.9 ADB is financing sewerage and drainage projects in 
secondary  cities.10 ADB  also  maintains  a  dialogue  with  the  Ha  Noi  University  of  Civil 
Engineering  on  technology  options,  in  particular  on  decentralized  wastewater  treatment 
alternatives. In 2010, Viet Nam achieved middle-income country status and the development 
partners are moving to less concessional lending. As such, ADB and the government need to 
prepare a gradual shift in financing the urban sanitation sector from Asian Development Fund

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be to contribute to the environmental sustainability of urban 
centers in Viet Nam. The outcome of the TA will be better prepared government agencies for 
the large-scale implementation of urban environmental improvement programs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will prepare central and local government agencies operating in the sector 
through training and capacity building to scale up program implementation and move forward 
the  policy  dialogue  by  (i)  assisting  in  the  drafting  of  the  new  legislation  for  wastewater 
management to supersede Decree 88/2007 and Circular 09/2009 (footnote 5); (ii) providing 
sustainable financing mechanisms, an enabling environment for private sector development, 
and affordable technological solutions in the form of customized road maps for each type of city, 
based on a comprehensive assessment of the sanitation sector; and (iii) building awareness 
and advocacy of municipal civil society. The TA aims to generate informed debate between 
agencies and individuals involved in specifying and deciding technological and financing options 
for wastewater collection, treatment, and disposal.  
 
10.  The TA will be delivered at three levels:  
 
(i)  central government—in assisting MOC with identifying strategic financial and technical 
options, designed to monitor sector performance, and with the review of wastewater 
legislation; 
(ii) local government—in guiding representatives from the departments and agencies of the 
selected cities and provinces on conducting financial assessments, preparing budget 
proposals, and setting tariffs; and 
(iii) water  and  sewerage  companies  or  URENCOs—in  preparing  them  for  their  role  in 
designing, planning, and managing wastewater management services, and operating on 
business principles, through on-the-job training. Training will be achieved through the 
process  of joint formulation  of  city  sanitation strategies  (CSSs)  for  up  to  15  cities, 
followed by more detailed ―options studies‖ or pre-feasibility studies for a selected group 
of up to five cities or towns. Pilot provinces, cities, and towns will be selected to provide 
a reasonable cross-section of socioeconomic and geographical conditions that will form 
the basis for future ADB lending in the urban environment. An additional criterion will be 
a clear commitment by local governments to achieve environmental improvements and a 
readiness to raise tariffs for better water and sanitation services. 
 
11.  Activities will be implemented in two parts over 24 months.  
 
12.   Part 1: City sanitation strategies and options studies (18 months). CSSs will be 
prepared for up to 15 cities and towns. The objectives are to (a) provide a rapid assessment of 
the city’s investment needs and options to improve the urban environment; (b) assess whether 
the city’s construction master plan and sewerage and drainage master plans are up-to-date and 
flexible enough to allow the phased implementation of a sewerage project; (c) determine the 
preparedness of local government agencies to assume the responsibility for planning, design, 
and operation and maintenance of sanitation; and (d) assess the relevance of key national

4   
legislation on urban drainage and sewerage (in particular, Decree 88/2007) in guiding future 
urban wastewater improvements in urban centers.  
 
13.  In  developing  programs  and  projects  for  sanitation  improvements,  several  strategic 
technical and financial options are available. Constructing conventional centralized sewerage 
systems in built-up urban areas is extremely complex, disruptive, and costly. Pragmatic and 
affordable alternatives need to be considered based on the outcome from the CSSs.11 Design 
approaches need to consider a phased introduction of affordable environmental improvements. 
Such considerations include a mix of centralized and decentralized systems, the promotion of 
low-cost  sanitation  technologies,  separate  versus  combined  wastewater  and  stormwater 
systems, the segregation or not of municipal and industrial wastewater, sludge and septage 
management strategies, and assessing the reuse of treated wastewater as a potential resource. 
Assessments of alternatives will consider sludge treatment and disposal, and energy usage to 
reduce the city carbon footprint and to contribute to the city climate change action plan.  
 
14.  Other  dedicated  programs  involve  schools,  reuse  of  water  and  organics,  and 
strengthening community awareness with a demand-driven approach to technology solutions, 
level of service, and tariffs. 
 
15.  Detailed options studies will be conducted at pre-feasibility stage for up to five cities or 
towns. The options studies will contain comprehensive assessments of the technical options, 
and outline financing arrangements for both capital costs and operating costs, with their subsidy 
and  tariff  implications,  and  an  advocacy  campaign  to  build  awareness  among  the 
representatives of civil society. A critical consideration will be the level of preparedness of the 
urban wastewater and drainage master plans.  
 
16.  Part  2:  Capacity  building  and  legal  framework  review  (12  months).  Capacity 
development of local government and URENCO staff will be provided as part of the CSS 
formulation process. Training materials will consolidate the work done by other development 
partners,  especially  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  and  will  build  on  those 
documents. For the central government, capacity development and training will follow a bottom-
up  approach,  using  the  lessons  learned  from  the  CSSs  and  options  studies,  and  further 
advance  the  preparation  of  procedures manuals,  which  will  include financial  and technical 
issues for formal government approval. Standard terms of reference will be prepared for use in 
future  project preparatory TA projects, highlighting key performance indicators to be monitored 
and sector issues to be considered during project preparation. Those documents will provide the 
basis for consistent and effective expansion of urban sanitation improvement programs in the 
future. National and local workshops will be held to discuss the manuals. 
 
17.  The ongoing assessment of legislation on drainage and sewerage will be consolidated 
and issued as a review of Decree 88/2007 (footnote 5) and its supporting Circular 09/2009. In 
cooperation with MOC and the Vietnam Water Supply and Sewerage Association (VWSA), key 
performance indicators will be proposed to help monitor progress in reaching national policy and 
urban wastewater targets, as formulated under Decision 1930/QD-TTg (footnote 4) and the 
upcoming Socioeconomic Development Plan, 2011–2015. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $2,250,000  equivalent.  The  Government  has 
requested ADB to finance $2,000,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The Government will finance

Up to 15 more will be conducted under this CDTA.

the  balance  of  the  cost  through  providing  counterpart  staff,  provision  of  office  space, 
communications facilities for consultants and other in-kind contributions  (see Appendix 2 for 
details of the cost estimates and financing plan). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  MOC's Department of Infrastructure will be the executing agency. The people's committees 
and  the  utility  companies  in  the  selected  pilot  provinces  and  cities  will  be  the  implementing 
agencies. MOC will ensure effective coordination with ADB, other central and local government 
agencies involved, and with the key development partners. Coordination will be  bolstered by 
stakeholder workshops that will present and discuss major project outputs and policy issues, 
review the progress of the TA, and provide directions for strategy formulation. The ADB water team
12 will assist with the logistics of procurement and management of the individual consultants and 
the consulting firm, and the dissemination of results through VWSA, Southeast Asia Water Utility 
Network, national and international conferences, and publications on ADB’s public website.  
 
20.  The  TA  will  finance  an  estimated  55  person-months  of  international  consultants  and 
99 person-months of national consultants over 24 months, from December 2011 to December 
2013. International and national consultants will be recruited as individual consultants and through 
a firm, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time). The firm is expected to be a national firm and will be chosen, through fixed budget 
selection based on a simplified technical proposal. The tasks to be performed by the firm do not 
require a specific expertise and the time and personnel inputs are clearly defined. The firm will 
manage the provisional sum for logistics and transport; social and technical surveys; translation 
and publication; and results dissemination. Equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and will be handed over to the 
executing agency, and to the local government agencies and URENCOs involved, at the end of the 
TA. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
21.  The team of consultants will operate under  the guidance of a senior urban sanitation 
strategy advisor who will ensure continuity with ADB’s policy and strategy for the water and 
sanitation sector in Viet Nam, and liaison between the government, ADB, and the consultants. 
Other specializations covered by the consultants include wastewater management engineering; 
wastewater treatment technology; sewer network collection; wastewater reuse, sludge and septage 
management;  social  development;  public  administration;  and  legal,  public,  and  private  sector 
finance.  The  terms  of  reference  are  in  Appendix  3.  ADB  will  manage  the  procurement  of 
consultants and equipment. ADB will seek MOC concurrence prior to recruiting consultants or 
purchasing equipment. 
 
22.  The  TA  outputs,  including  knowledge  products  and  services,  will  be  disseminated  to 
intended users through workshops, electronic reports, website publication, and other means to be 
specified in a knowledge dissemination and communication plan. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
23.  The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to the Government of Viet Nam to be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  for  Support  to  Central  and  Local 
Governments to Implement Urban Environmental Improvement Programs. 
                                                
12 In 2009, ADB set up a water team of two international consultants and one national consultant to assist with the sector 
work and with leveraging ADB's lending pipeline in the water and sanitation sector.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Background and Objective  
1.  The capacity development technical assistance (TA) project is based on the findings of the 
2010  Viet  Nam  Water  Sector  Assessment,  Strategy  and  Roadmap,  which  found  that  urban 
wastewater management was one of the areas with a significant gap between the current coverage 
(less than 10% of urban households) and government targets for the subsector (full collection and 
treatment of wastewater for cities of Class IV and above, by 2025). The TA design recognizes the 
shortage of relevant skills and experience within those subnational agencies that have been made 
responsible for dealing with urban wastewater and drainage, and thereby for meeting government 
targets. Since only a few urban centres in Viet Nam have full sewerage systems, local government 
planners and decision makers have not been exposed to technology alternatives for wastewater 
management. The TA design further recognizes  that  despite  the  explicit  government  targets, 
wastewater  management  may  not  yet  have  gained  the  full  sociopolitical  priority  required  to 
successfully compete for funding allocations.  
2.  Reaching government targets will require considerable funding for capital works, as well as 
increasing and sustained income to fund recurrent costs. As Viet Nam's eligibility for grants and 
concessional loans declines after having reached the status of a middle-income country, other 
means of financing must be determined and developed. ADB’s strategy for the urban wastewater 
sector  in  Viet  Nam  is  therefore  to  gradually  prepare  for  a  broad-based  comprehensive  and 
sustained program that combines strengthening skills and awareness with providing funding, while 
simultaneously identifying and leveraging additional sources of finance. 
3.  The TA will assist the Government of Viet Nam in preparing the implementation of a large-
scale  and  long-term  urban  wastewater  management  program  under  the  decentralized 
responsibility of provincial and city governments. This preparation entails assessing the institutional 
change, advocacy, and training needs required to support such a program, and introducing funding 
strategies that can support an ―evolutive‖ approach to technical design. The TA will make a start 
with the delivery of advocacy and training, and will define and formulate the structure of the future 
program. It will operate at multiple levels of government—central, provincial, and city. 
4.  The TA for urban environmental improvement forms part of ADB’s phased program to help 
the government achieve its target for urban drainage of stormwater and wastewater:  
(i)  Two initial city sanitation strategies (CSSs) were established in 2010, assessing data 
availability and investment needs, and discussing broad policy issues locally.  
(ii)   Thes TA (2011–2012) will further determine local technical, institutional, and financial 
needs, consolidate findings from all pertinent initiatives into a comprehensive sector 
assessment, and define pragmatic and targeted project preparatory TA.  
(iii)   A project preparatory TA is planned for 2012–2013, to formulate a sustainable long-
term future loan program.  
(iv)  Loan funding shall be made available through a multitranche financing facility—a line 
of credit to run from 2013 to 2022, to facilitate the funding of high-priority urban 
sanitation and wastewater management interventions, in the project preparatory TA 
cities as well as other urban areas.  
(v)   In parallel, ADB will review the provision of guarantees (2013–2020) as a mechanism 
to encourage public–private partnerships for the urban wastewater sector. 
5.  The  TA  will  center  on  the  CSS  formulation  for  up  to  15  cities,  followed  by  more 
comprehensive options studies for five selected cities. The TA is intended to establish a stronger 
institutional basis for a future project preparatory TA on urban wastewater management. The TA 
will:

Appendix 3  11 
(i)   encourage  a  focused  and  sustained  policy  dialogue—and  thereby  stronger 
institutional awareness—among central government agencies on urban wastewater 
strategies, involving both technical and financial issues; 1  
(ii)   highlight  from  direct  experience  the  critical  institutional  constraints  of  subnational 
agencies;  
(iii)   define a pragmatic mix of finance options to fund a long-term program; and  
(iv)  document the most suitable technology options for wastewater collection and treatment, 
for on-site, decentralized, and centralized alternatives.  
6.  The  TA  will  encourage  government  to  consider  innovative  technical  options  in  urban 
wastewater management, and to disseminate the findings as part of governmental guidelines. 
Engineering approaches should allow for a gradual implementation of infrastructure improvements, 
based on a ―no-regrets‖ first-phase investment, e.g., in decentralized wastewater collection and 
treatment. System designs shall include comprehensive means of dealing with sewage sludge and 
septage. For parts of the city where septic tanks will continue to be in use, the proposed program 
will include means to improve their environmental functioning by safely removing and disposing 
sludge. Local reuse of treated wastewater will be encouraged 
B.  Detailed Tasks 
7.  The TA will run for about 24 months, from December 2011, and requires an estimated 
55 person-months  of  international  consultants  supported  by  99  person-months  of  national 
consultants.  International  consultants  will  be  recruited  as  individual  consultants  and  national 
consultants through a firm, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, 
as amended from time to time). The firm is expected to be a national firm and will be recruited 
through fixed budget selection based on a simplified technical proposal. The firm will manage the 
provisional sum for logistics and transport, translation, and surveys. Equipment will be procured in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and will be 
handed over to the executing agency and the local agencies involved at the end of the TA. 
8.  Phasing of tasks. The TA has two partly concurrent parts, with identifiable deliverables 
and milestones. The consultants are expected to make an immediate start on interaction with the 
Government of Viet Nam, benefiting from the experience of recently done work on urban sanitation 
and wastewater in the country, as documented in the ―Viet Nam Urban Sanitation Issues Paper‖ by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Ministry of Construction (MOC).  
(i)  Part 1—city sanitation strategies and training (18 months). Preparation of CSSs 
for up to 15 cities and towns, to provide rapid assessment of investment needs, state 
of master plans, and capacity development needs. On-the-job training through joint 
formulation of investment plans. Initial assessment of legislation (Decree 88/2007). 
More detailed assessment of technical options and possible financing arrangements 
for up to five towns best placed for future investment. 
(ii)  Part 2—capacity building and legal framework review (12 months). Preparation of 
draft  procedures  manuals,  as  basis  for  guiding  the  government's  future  urban 
sanitation improvement program. Formulation of performance Indicators to monitor 
progress against policy targets. Recommendation of changes to legislation (Decree 
88/2007, in particular).  
 
9.  Team Leader – Senior Urban Sanitation Strategy Advisor (international, 12 person-
months). The consultant should have 15 years of experience in urban environment and pollution 
                                                
1  This particularly concerns the Ministry of Planning and Investment, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Construction (MOC), 
and the State Bank of Viet Nam.

12          Appendix 3 
 
control, preferably including experience  in the policy aspects of urban services management; 
experience in conducting feasibility and sector studies in Southeast Asia, preferably including Viet 
Nam. He or she must have demonstrable experience as team leader of interdisciplinary projects. 
The consultant will have overall responsibility for team management, study guidance, and delivery 
of outputs, as well as quality control. He or she will: 
(i)  Assume overall responsibility for the delivery of the project, coordinate and manage 
the team of consultants, liaise with government and with development partners, to 
ensure compatibility and to avoid duplication and inconsistency in approaches.  
(ii)  Assess  the  current  situation  in  urban  sanitation  and  wastewater  management; 
conduct further research and interviews with government officials and representatives 
from development partners; formulate detailed program outputs with an updated work 
plan in close coordination with MOC, the Ministry of Planning and Investment, and 
ADB; finalize the selection of the pilot provinces and towns; and ensure formal written 
agreement.  
(iii)  Identify  and  inventory  existing  technology  options,  including  both  centralized  and 
decentralized systems; guide process of CSSs and subsequent options studies; and 
analyze and consolidate findings in final reports.  
(iv)  Monitor the preparation of project outputs and deliverables, in particular procedures 
manuals  on  urban  wastewater  for  MOC,  ensuring  policy  and  presentational 
consistency and maintaining quality control.  
 
10.  Wastewater infrastructure engineering and treatment specialists (4 international, 30 
person-months; 6 national—deputy team leader, senior and junior specialists—73 person-months). 
The consultants will: 
(i)  From  reports  and  brief  site  visits,  assess  the  current  state  of  environmental 
management practices and priorities in Vietnamese urban areas; assess technical 
capacities of local urban environmental companies (URENCOs) and water supply and 
sewerage companies.  
(ii)  Review current legislation, regulation, and guidelines relevant to urban wastewater 
and drainage; review existing handbooks and training manuals;2 prepare the technical 
component of the procedures manuals; liaise and work closely with key engineering 
and research institutions in Viet Nam to benefit from earlier work done (e.g., on 
decentralized wastewater collection and treatment) and for analysis of combined vs. 
separate systems. 
(iii)  Present in a CSS a clear outline analysis of alternatives to centralized or decentra-
lized systems, potential for reuse, separate or combined wastewater and stormwater 
systems, combining or separating municipal and industrial wastewater, wastewater 
treatment options, sludge and septage treatment and disposal, energy considerations, 
and approaches to operation and maintenance. In the subsequent options studies, 
further refine (with a financial analyst) design and funding options.  
(iv)  Assess resilience and vulnerability of existing urban infrastructure to climate change, 
include adaptation measures in planning, and outline design procedures.  
(v)  Collaborate with local government and water supply and sewerage companies or 
URENCOs in preparing the CSSs and options studies for the selected pilot towns. 
Apply the proposed procedures to the actual situation in the pilot towns, to determine 
(a)  an  outline  of  technical  approach,  (b)  preliminary  cost  estimate,  (c)  resource 
implications  such  as  funding  and  skills  requirements;  and  (d)  proposed  funding 
arrangements and tariff implications.  
 
                                                
2  In particular those prepared for MOC under the project ―Wastewater and solid waste management in provincial 
centres‖ funded by German development cooperation through GTZ.

Appendix 3  13 
11.  Social and/or institutional development advisor (international, 4 person-months). He or 
she will: 
(i)  Assess  and  describe  community  attitudes  toward  urban  environmental  issues, 
including awareness of household responsibility for sanitation; consider specific needs 
and priorities of peri-urban communities; assess and describe in broad terms the 
socioeconomic and health impacts of inadequate urban environmental services on 
urban communities, in particular on households in under-served and peri-urban areas. 
(ii)  Collect and analyze secondary data on urban poverty, and occurrence of temporary 
settlements;  and  provide  household  income  and  expenditure  data  to  assist  in 
determining affordability of fees and charges.  
(iii)  Recommend  strategies  and  means  for  urban  service  companies  to  promote  the 
consultation  and  participation  of  women  in  urban  communities,  and  greater 
involvement and employment of women in urban environmental management.  
(iv)  Prepare recommendations on initiatives to improve awareness of the value of better 
wastewater management among central and local decision makers and among urban 
communities.  
 
12.  Financial specialists (2 international, 6 person-months; 2 national, 18 person-months). 
The consultants must have 10 years of experience in the financial analysis of public and private 
sector investment for urban infrastructure development, and will: 
(i)  Conduct an analysis of the current structure of service fees within urban areas, and of 
discharge  fees  under  environmental  and  drainage  legislation;  assess  ranges  of 
household and agency affordability; review the system of provincial allocations for 
urban services and infrastructure provision; prepare a study on financing options, 
clearly  presenting  options  for  funding  (a)  capital  works  and  (b)  operating  costs; 
present options for access to possible sources of international grant funding, as a 
transition toward greater financial sustainability of the sector. 
(ii)  Take lead role in formulating and delivering the financial management component of 
the capacity development program, aimed at MOC, the ministries of finance and of 
planning and investment, and counterpart departments within provincial governments. 
(iii)  Determine opportunities for private sector involvement, assess the current regulatory 
framework, and deduce implications for potential private sector interest; assess the 
constitutional position of URENCOs; assess the financial viability of issuing loans to 
public and private sector borrowers, and recommend a guarantee structure for private 
sector borrowers; and pinpoint public–private partnership opportunities in urban utility 
organizations. 
(iv)  Discuss with provincial people’s committees the implications for tariffs for wastewater 
under existing legislation, suggest a methodology for calculating tariffs in line with 
current legislation, and assess attitudes toward levying tariffs for wastewater. 
(v)  Outline alternatives for funding capital works as well as recurrent expenditures, and 
review and present policy options for a system of (transitional) subsidies to achieve 
urban environmental improvement targets. 
 
13.  Legal advisers (1 international, 2 person-months; 1 national, 6 person-months) will:  
(i)  Provide a concise overview of the legal framework governing the provision of urban 
environmental infrastructure and consolidate the ongoing reviews of Decree 88/2007 
and Circular 09/2009 into a formal set of recommendations for possible amendments. 
(ii)  Assist  MOC  in  establishing  monitoring  instruments  and  indicators,  and  reliable 
mechanisms  for  collecting  and  verifying  indicators  that  reflect  progress  in 
implementing government policies, particularly Decree 88/2007; involve the Vietnam

14          Appendix 3 
 
Water Supply and Sewerage Association (as well as other development partners) in a 
review of the present benchmarking process. 
 
C.  Reporting and Deliverables 
14.  Reports will be prepared in English and Vietnamese to facilitate government understanding 
and decision making. Reports will be submitted in both electronic and paper form. All data and 
analyses will be consolidated and provided to the government in electronic form. The following 
reports will be prepared: 
(i)  Inception report—summarizing the key issues for the urban wastewater sector and 
confirming the TA work plan, this will for the basis for discussion at the inception 
workshop. 
(ii)  City sanitation strategy report—one for each selected pilot city (up to 15 cities).  
(iii)  Interim report—to summarize progress in working with the provinces and the pilot 
cities, and provide a provisional review of legislation.  
(iv)  Options studies—one each for five selected pilot cities, these are a precursor to the 
project  preparatory  TA  feasibility  work,  with  an  outline  physical  plan  as  well  as 
preliminary cost estimates, institutional assessment, and outline financing proposal. 
(v)  Legislative  review—a  final  assessment  of  policy,  legislation,  and  regulation 
concerning the urban drainage and wastewater sector, in particular Decree 88/2007 
and Circular 09/2009, with recommendations for update and revision.  
(vi)  Performance  indicators—to  assist  central  government  (MOC  and  the  Ministry  of 
Planning and Investment) in the process of guiding and monitoring progress against 
sector policy and targets. 
(vii)  Procedures manuals for urban wastewater—to guide provincial and local government 
agencies in the preparation of and budgeting for their respective urban wastewater 
and sanitation improvement plans.  
(viii)  Final report—including an evaluation of the experience gained in the preparation of 
the CSSs and options studies in all pilot cities, and an update of the procedures 
manuals.  
 
15.  Three copies of each report (in English) will be submitted to ADB and 10 copies (in both 
Vietnamese and English) to the executing agency. The reports should discuss all aspects of the 
terms of reference to a level of detail appropriate for the given component of the TA.  
16.  The  consultants  will  present  key  findings  in  a  number  of  workshops  and  seminars. 
Members of the central and provincial governments, the executing agency, other key agencies, 
local communities, and ADB staff will participate in the workshops. Tripartite meetings will be 
organized after the submission and review of the inception report, the interim report, and the draft 
final report. The consultants will assist ADB in preparing the draft TA report. 
17.  The following workshops or seminars are planned: 
(i)  Inception workshop—to present the inception report and to discuss the scope of the 
project and its policy objectives, along with the broader framework of the proposed 
long-term central government program. 
(ii)  Interim workshop—to present the consolidated findings from the CSSs (Part 1), to 
discuss the provisional review of legislation, and to present the proposed work plan 
for Part 2. 
(iii)  Presentations, centrally and in the provinces, of the draft procedures manuals, in the 
presence of agency representatives from the selected towns. 
(iv)  Final dissemination workshop—to present and discuss the results of the case studies 
in pilot cities (centrally, with provincial and city government and agencies invited).
